journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Performance analysis of screw compressors – numerical simulation and experimental verification

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, Taiwan, Republic of China
2Fu Sheng Industrial Co., Ltd., Taipei County, Taiwan, Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, 168 University Road, Ming-Hsiung, Chia-Yi 621, Republic of China. email: imewhh@ccu.edu.tw

abstract.p: This article describes a theoretical model and computer program for calculating the pressure–volume (PV ) diagram and the efficiency of an oil-injected screw compressor. The proposed model considers the mass and energy conservation laws, the heat transfer between air and oil, the leakages through various paths, and the discharges of air and oil. The proposed program, which uses seven empirical constants to account for the difference between the flow and the heat-transfer rates in the screw compressor and those estimated by available correlations, solves for the efficiency and the pressure curve of the compressed air. A systematic methodology for the determination of the seven empirical constants is presented in this article. Optimization is carried out to determine the seven empirical constants. With the empirical constants, which are determined with four sets of experiments, the maximum difference between the calculated and measured results in the training process, the verification process and the total process is 2.0 per cent for the volumetric and isentropic efficiencies and 5 per cent for the pressure curve. In the discharge process, the pressure in the compression chamber is noted to be affected by the area of the outlet port and the pressure in the neighbouring chambers.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The operating principle of the oil-injected screw compressor is that the meshing screws compress the air via the variable volumes of the chambers formed by the lobes of the screws and the case. During the compressing process, a precise amount of oil is injected at a precise time in a specific location. This oil lubricates the rotating screws and decreases the temperature of the compressed air to a safe working range of 80–95°C [1]. The oil-injected screw compressor is widely used in the mining industry, chemical industry, construction, mechanical projects and refrigeration, among others, for its reliability, versatility of compressing different mediums, good dynamic balance, and others.

In recent years, the design of the oil-injected screw compressor has generally involved numerical design tools for generating the geometric profile of the screw, for performing the thermo-fluidic analysis and for calculating the deformations of the screw caused by mechanical loads and heat. The results obtained using these design tools are then merged and iterated to optimize the design parameters for the highest volumetric and isentropic efficiencies. When conducting a thermo-fluidic analysis of an oil-injected screw compressor, the entire compression cycle is generally described by the conservation of mass and energy and the equation of state for the compressed medium, as indicated in previous studies [2–10]. In order to close the model, a number of correlations, which may contain empirical constants, were often used in these studies to calculate the leakage flowrates, discharge flowrate, heat-transfer rates, and others. The empirical constants were used to account for the difference between the actual flowrates and/or heat-transfer rates in oil-injected screw compressor and those estimated by the correlations available in open literature. Fleming et al. [4] considered four kinds of leakage paths inside the screw compressor, and used empirical constants to calculate the flowrates through the four kinds of leakage paths. Li et al. [6] used one empirical constant to calculate the flowrate through each of the four kinds of leakage paths, and another empirical constant to calculate the flowrate of discharge. Wu et al. [9] used one empirical constant to calculate the flowrate through each of the four kinds of leakage paths, one empirical constant to calculate the flowrate of discharge, and one empirical constant to calculate the rate of heat transfer between the compressed air and oil. The number and values of these empirical constants in these studies are noted to be different and dependent on the compressor design.

In general, the predicted results of volumetric and isentropic efficiencies in these studies were in good agreement with the experimental results. However, the PV diagrams of the compressed gas based on computations and experiments did not entirely agree, especially not for the pressure peaks. These disagreements affect the accuracy of analysing the loading and thermal deformations and consequently influence the entire optimization. Therefore, there is room for improvement in the thermo-fluidic model for the design of a screw compressor. In addition, the way to determine the empirical constants for calculating the leakage flowrates, discharge flowrate, and heat-transfer rates in a screw compressor have not been investigated systematically. This study establishes a theoretical model and a computer program for simulating the compression processes of oil-injected screw compressors. Seven empirical constants are used in the model to account for the difference between the flow and heat-transfer rates in the screw compressor and those estimated by available correlations. The empirical constants are determined systematically in a training process and verified by several sets of experimental results. The verified theoretical model and computer program can simulate and explain the detailed compression processes under various operating conditions, and be used for the thermo-fluidic analysis in the coupled design of an oil-injected screw compressor.

sec.title: 2.1 Physical model and the governing equations
sec.p:
The physical model of this study considers a deformable control volume that represents one of the compression chambers of an oil-injected screw compressor. Figure 1 shows the control volume, which is filled with air and oil. The model considers the equations of the conservation of mass and energy for the air and the oil, and the equation of state for the air. On the boundary of the control volume, the entrance of the air, the injection of the oil, the discharges of the air and the oil, and the leakages through the contact line, sealing line, blow hole, and ends of screws are considered. Within the control volume, the heat transfer between the air and the oil and that between the air and the oil film are also included in the model. Fig. 1
Physical model of the compressing chamber in a screw compressor
Equation (1) is the mass conservation for the air. This equation relates the change of the air mass in the control volume to the mass flowrates of the inlet, discharge and leakage of air (1)
Equation (2) is the mass conservation for the oil. This equation relates the change of oil mass in the control volume to the mass flowrates of injection, discharge and leakage of oil (2)

The first law of thermodynamics is applied to the air and the oil within the control volume. In equation (3), the rate of change of the internal energy of the air is influenced by the inlet and discharge of the air, the heat transfer between the air and the oil and the compression. The potential and kinetic energies of the air are neglected in the equation since they are negligible compared with the internal energy of the air (3)
Similarly, the change of the internal energy of oil is influenced by the injection, discharge and leakage of the oil, and the heat transfer from the air to the oil (4)

The pressure and temperature of the air range from 0 to 29.61 atm and from room temperature to 120°C, respectively, during a compressing cycle. Under these conditions, the air can be treated as an ideal gas [11]. The specific heat, viscosity, and speed of sound are functions of the temperature. The ideal-gas equation of state for air is shown in equation (5) (5)

sec.title: 2.2 Leakage and discharge
sec.p: The entrance, discharge, and leakage of the air and oil are also considered in the theoretical model of this study. This study assumes that air and oil (mixed fluid) are well mixed and flow through these paths. The temperature and pressure of the air outside both the inlet and the outlet are constant. In addition, the temperature and the injected flowrate of the oil are constants as well.

In a complete compression cycle, four kinds of leakage [2] are considered in this study. One of the leakages flows through the contact line, which divides the compression chamber into sections of low and high pressures. Two of the leakages flow between the compression chambers through the blow holes and the sealing lines. The last one flows through the ends of the screws of the compressor. This study calculates the mass flowrates of these leakages by equation (6) [4]. In equation (6), ξ is the empirical constant for calculating the mass flowrate. Since there are four kinds of leakage, the mass flowrate of leakage through the blow hole is calculated by ξblow, the one through the sealing line by ξsealing, the one through the ends ofthe screws by ξend, and the one through the contact line by ξcontact (6)
where Math={2k-1[(PdownstreamPupstream)(1-k)/k-1]}1/2 is the Mach number of the mixed fluid under the isentropic ideal condition.

Within the compression chamber, the mixed fluid is driven axially by the compression chamber and is moving at the same speed as the compression chamber. At the exit, the mixed fluid is discharged in the axial direction and is therefore influenced by the pressure difference across the outlet and the axial velocity of the mixed fluid driven by the compression chamber. This study considers these two effects and adopts equation (7) in its calculations. In equation (7), ξp and ξsv represent the relative contributions of the pressure difference [12] and the axial velocity of the mixed fluid, respectively. In addition, the mass flowrates of air and oil can be derived individually from the mass flowrate of the mixed fluid and the mass fractions of air and oil (7)

sec.title: 2.3 Heat transfer between air and oil
sec.p: The temperature of the compressed air in a screw compressor is raised as a result of the compression. If the air temperature exceeds a preset safety limit, the lifetime of the compressor will be reduced. For this reason, oil is injected at the appropriate location during the compression cycle to lower the temperature of the compressed air and lubricate the screws as they mesh with each other.

In the past, the motion and heat transfer of the oil within a compression chamber were investigated by various researchers. Stosic et al. [7] described the flying path as the oil is injected into the compressor in the form of drops. They showed that after a period of flying time the oil drops attach to the surface inside the compression chamber by centrifugal force. Zamfirescu et al. [10] simulated the motion of the liquid drop inside the screw compressor through computational fluid dynamic calculations. They showed that the liquid drop flies away from the centre of the screw under the effect of the centrifugal force and becomes a liquid film attached to the inside surface of the compressor. Therefore, the heat transfers between the air and the oil drops and between the air and the oil film both need to be taken into consideration. In this study, as shown in Fig. 1, oil is assumed to enter the compressor in the form of drops, and the rate of the heat transfer between the air and the oil drops is calculated by equation (8). Inthis equation, hoil drop is the heat convective coefficient between the air and the oil drops, and it is calculated by equation (9) [4, 6, 7, 9, 10] (8) (9)

After being injected into the compression chamber, the oil drops will eventually fall onto the inner surface of the compression chamber and form an oil film. Since the air inside the compression chamber flows over the oil film, the heat transfer between the air and the oil film is considered to be forced convection and is calculated by equation (10) [5, 10]. The convective heat transfer coefficient, hoil film, is calculated by equation (11) (10) (11)

sec.title: 2.4 Efficiencies
sec.p: The isentropic and volumetric efficiencies are the two most important performance characteristics of a screw compressor. In this study, the power of isentropic compression divided by the input shaft power equals the isentropic efficiency and is calculated by equation (12). In this equation, the power of isentropic compression is obtained by equation (13). The input shaft power, W·shaft, is measured by the torque meter on the transmission shaft in the experiments and is calculated by summing the power for compressing the gas and the power losses due to oil lubrication in the computer program (12) (13) The actual volumetric flowrate divided by the ideal volumetric flowrate equals the volumetric efficiency and is calculated by equation (14). In this equation, the ideal volumetric flowrate, qvt, is obtained by equation (15). The actual volumetric flowrate, qv, of the experiment is measured by the flow meter and is calculated by the numerical program in the discharge process. The geometric parameters, used for calculating the ideal volumetric flowrate with equation (15), of the screw compressor are the coefficient of the twist angle (Cφ = 0.9850), the coefficient of the usage area (CA = 0.4511), the aspect ratio (ψ = 1.619), and the diameter of male screw (D = 0.1131 m) (14) (15)

sec.title: 2.5 Empirical constants and numerical method
sec.p: In this study, seven empirical constants are used to account for the difference between the actual thermal and flow properties in the oil-injected screw compressor and those estimated by existing correlations. Four of them, ξblow, ξsealing, ξend, and ξcontact, calculate the mass flowrates of leakages. They are the ratios of the actual mass flowrates through the blow hole, the sealing line, the ends of the screws, and the contact line, to those calculated under the isentropic ideal condition, respectively. The empirical constant, ξheat, used in the heat transfer equations is the ratio of the actual heat transfer between the gas and oil to that calculated by the empirical correlation developed by Refs [5, 9]. The two empirical constants, ξp and ξsv, calculate the velocity of mixed fluid for the determination of the discharge mass flowrate. The one, ξp, is the ratio of the actual velocity of mixed fluid driven by the pressure difference to that calculated under isentropic ideal condition. Another one, ξsv, is the ratio of the actual axial velocity of mixed fluid to the moving forward speed of the compression chamber tangent to the shaft of screws.

In this study, the above-mentioned model is solved numerically, and optimization is used to determine the seven empirical constants. The computing procedure is shown in Fig. 2. The procedure is started by inputting the initial conditions and the initial guesses of the empirical constants. Two iteration loops, r and s, are required to solve the model and the empirical constants. The inner loop (r) solves the governing equations using the method of Runge–Kutta–Fehlberg [13] with a given set of empirical constants and then outputs the volumetric efficiency and the PVdiagram. The convergence criterion for the inner loop shown in equation (16) is set to be 10−3, which guarantees accurate and stable results. In equation (16), the second term is the mean value of the absolute relative pressure differences between two consecutive iterations at 655 compressing angles during a completer compression cycle (0–730°). In addition, a verification of the numerical program, solving the inner loop, is also carried out by comparing the numerical and the analytical solutions of the air temperature and pressure during an isentropic compression process. The verification indicates that results from the numerical program compare well with the analytical solutions (16) The outer loop (s) based on the method of sequential quadratic programming [14–17] determines the seven empirical constants by minimizing the difference between the calculated and measured isentropic efficiencies, volumetric efficiencies, and PV diagrams. The objective function, equation (17), used in the optimal computing is a function of the results obtained by the inner loop (r), the experimental data and the weighting factors [18, 19]. In equation (17), the four differences between the calculated and measured pressure curves are calculated during the compression (386–637°, i = 3), start of discharge (637–660°, i = 4), middle of discharge (660–710°, i = 5), and end of discharge (710–730°, i = 6) processes of a compression cycle, respectively. Each of them is the mean value of the absolute relative differences between the calculated and measured pressures at 128–222 angles (the number of angles depends on the rotational speed of the compressor) during a compression cycle. The outer loop iterates until the changes in the objective function and empirical constants are less than 10−6 and 10−4, respectively (17) where C is the weighting factor, sum (C ) the sum of all weighting factors, z the measured result, ythe calculated result, i the index of the difference between the calculated and the measured results, i = 1 the difference of volumetric efficiency, i = 2 the difference of isentropic efficiency, i = 3–6 the differences of PV diagrams, and j the index of the measured result. Fig. 2
Flow chart of computer code

sec.title: 2.6 Experimental setup
sec.p:
In order to provide experimental data for the determination of empirical constants, an experimental facility was set up in this study. Figure 3 shows the schematic diagram of the experimental facility. A DC motor operates the screw compressor (Fu Sheng Industrial Co., Limited). A torque meter and a rotational speed meter are installed on the transmission shaft to measure the input torque and the rotational speed of the shaft, respectively. During operation, the air flows into the compressor through the inlet, and oil is injected into the compressor through an injecting port. Inside the compression chamber of the screw compressor, the air and oil are mixed and compressed. The compressed mixed fluid discharges through the outlet of the screw compressor and flows into an oil/gas separator in order to separate the air and the oil. The separated air and oil then flow through an air cooler through separate pipes. After cooling, the air is dried by a water filter. The dried air passes through a back-pressure regulator and an air flow meter. Then, the air is discharged to the ambient. On the other hand, the cooled oil flows through an oil flow meter and is re-injected into the compressor. Fig. 3
Schematic diagram of the experimental facility

To measure the pressures of both air and oil, pressure gauges are installed on the outside of the inlet and on the outlet of the compressor, the oil/gas separator and the outlet of the air flow meter. For temperature measurements, thermocouples are installed at the inlet and outlet of the compressor, the oil injection line and the outlet of the air flow meter. To measure the flowrates of the air and the oil, an air flow meter and an oil flow meter are installed in the system. In order to determine the PV diagram during a test condition, the pressure inside the compression chamber is measured by two pressure transducers (Kulite-XTL-140(M)), and the rotational angle is measured by an encoder (HEIDENHAIN ROD 486), as shown in Fig. 4. One pressure transducer is located in the male screw, 3 mm from the entrance end of the screw, for measuring the pressure during the suction at the beginning of the compression process. The other pressure transducer is installed in the female screw, 3 mm from the discharge end of the screw, and measures the pressure during both the compression and the discharge processes. The outputs from both pressure transducers are recorded, through two slip rings, by a data acquisition A/D card (NI PCI-6071E) installed on a personal computer. Fig. 4
Sensors and data acquisition system for the determination of the PV diagram

The uncertainty of the deduced data is determined as the sum of the random and systematic errors [20,21]. The random error is determined from replicated test results with the Student’s t-statistic at a probability of 95 per cent. In order to estimate the systematic error, the sensitivities of the parameters which describe the data are first determined based on the relationship between the parameters and the data. The systematic error is then calculated with the determined sensitivities and the specification of the measurement instrument (Table 1). The pressure measurement has anuncertainty of ±1.59 per cent. The uncertainty of the volumetric efficiency is about ±0.51 per cent. The uncertainty of the isentropic efficiency is ±0.74 per cent. In order to verify the theoretical model and to train the empirical constants accurately, the eight test conditions, as shown in Table2, were designed to obtain the measured efficiencies and pressure curves. Table 2 shows theeight test conditions of this study. Seven of these eight test conditions are adopted to compare the effect of the rotational speed (experimental conditions 1, 2, and 4), the discharge pressure (experimental conditions 3, 5, and 8) and the flowrate oftheoil injection (experimental conditions 4, 5, and6). In addition, one test condition with a random parameter setting is also included (experimental condition 7). Table 1
The uncertainties of the experimental apparatus

sec.title: 3.1 Prediction of the computer code
sec.p: The following predictions were made to show the capabilities of the theoretical model and the numerical program. In this study, based on one set of experimental data, a set of empirical constants were determined by minimizing the differences between the experimental and the calculated results of the isentropic and volumetric efficiencies and the PV diagrams. This procedure is called a training process. The test condition under which the training experimental data are obtained is referred to as the training condition. In this part of study, the training process is carried out with the experimental data obtained under test condition 1, as shown in Table 2. After the training process is accomplished, the experimental and calculated results under the training condition (test condition 1) are compared with each other. Their relative differences between the calculated and measured isentropic efficiency (Eisen) and volumetric efficiency (Evol), calculated by equation (18), are 0.59 per cent and 0.46 per cent, respectively (18) In addition, the calculated root mean relative difference Ep [equation (19)] between the calculated and measured pressure curves is 2.98 per cent. This shows that the trained numerical program is able to provide accurate results under the training condition. (19) where Pcal is the calculated pressure, Pexp the measured pressure, a the index of the specific angles, and I the total number of specific angles during a compression process.

Figure 5(a) shows the comparison between the calculated and the experimental pressure curves. In addition, Fig. 5(B) compares the pressure curves of the compression chamber under consideration as well as its neighbours and shows the variation in the outlet port area during the discharge process. In Fig. 5(A), the whole compression cycle is divided into three sections. Section (I) is the suction process, section (II) the compression process, which starts as soon as the inlet port is closed, and section (III) the discharge process, which begins when the outlet port opens. In addition, the discharge process is divided into another four segments, (a), (b), (c), and (d), as shown in the enlarged view in Fig. 5(a). Fig. 5
(a) Comparison of calculated and measured pressures as a function of angle. The insert shows the pressure variation during the discharge process. (b) Pressure variations of the qconsidered, the preceding (q + 1), and the following (q − 1) compression chambers during the discharge process, and the discharge area of the compression chamber considered

Figure 5(b) and Table 3 show the relationship between the gas pressure of the compression chamber under consideration and its neighbours during the discharge process, in order to describe the changes of the gas mass in the compression chamber under consideration and the changes of the outlet port area in relation to the compression chambers. Segment (a) in Fig. 5(b) is the start of the discharge process and is located between the angles of 613.45° and 620°. In this segment, the gas pressure in the compression chamber under consideration (q) is lower than the back pressure (7.74 atm) and lower than the pressure in the preceding compression chamber (q + 1). The gas flows back to the compression chamber under consideration from the preceding compression chamber and from the region outside the outlet port. The gas mass in the compression chamber under consideration increases, and the gas pressure also increases. Table 3
The relationship between the compression chambers and the outlet port, and the variation of the air mass in the chamber
Region Outlet port corresponding to chamber
Preceding compression chamber (q + 1) Considered compression chamber (q) Following compression chamber (q − 1) Air mass in the considered compression chamber
III-a Open Open Close Increasing
III-b Open Open Close Decreasing
III-c Close Open Close Decreasing
III-d Close Open Open Decreasing

Since the gas pressure is higher than the back pressure (7.74 atm), the discharge process goes into segment (b). Figure 5(b) shows that the gas pressure in compression chamber (q) is affected by the gas pressure in the preceding compression chamber (q + 1), which is also part of the discharge process. The discharge port is still small and consequently, the resistance to gas flow through the discharge port is large. Thus, the gas pressure continues to increase and the first pressure peak appears near the angle of 632°. The first pressure peak in the compression chamber (q) begins to diminish when the discharge port area is large enough to relieve the pressure. The rapidly increasing pressure in the preceding compression chamber causes the gas pressure in compression chamber (q) to experience another, but smaller, peak at an angle of 650°.

When the angle increases to more than 660° (the preceding compression chamber has completed its discharge process at this angle), the discharge process goes into segment (c). The area of the outlet port is now large enough for the gas to be exhausted steadily. The gas pressure in compression chamber (q) is maintained at a stable exhaust pressure. When the angle increases to more than 685.45°, the discharge process goes into segment (d), and it is easy to see the large amplitude of the peak in the gas pressure in compression chamber (q). This pressure peak is caused by the continually decreasing area of the outlet port and the increasing gas pressure in the following compression chamber (q − 1), which starts the discharge process. The above explanation shows that the trained numerical program can accurately describe the variations in the pressure curves under the training condition.

In order to see whether the above trained numerical program is able to obtain the same accurate results under the experimental conditions other than the training condition (experimental condition 1), the performances of the compressor under the second to the eighth experimental conditions listed in Table 2 were calculated by the trained numerical program. This procedure is called the verification process. The average relative difference between the calculated and measured isentropic efficiencies in this verification process is 1.85 per cent and that between the calculated and measured volumetric efficiencies is 3.53 per cent. The average root mean relative difference between the calculated and measured pressure curves is 4.90 per cent. They are all larger than the ones in the training process. Under the different training conditions or the different inputs of initial guesses of the optimization, the numerical program, which has been trained by the training process, was not guaranteed to give the same precise results. This process is capable of further improvement.

sec.title: 3.2 Determination of empirical constants by making use of measured data derived from a range of different experimental conditions
sec.p:
The following are the optimization results when the numerical program is trained with multiple training conditions. The calculation conditions of this optimization are listed in Table 4. The calculation conditions 1–4 adopt one set, two sets, four sets, and eight sets of training conditions, respectively, and they all use the same initial guesses of the seven empirical constants. Table 4
Difference between the calculated and measured results, and calculation time under the four calculation conditions
Calculation condition Experimental condition listed in Table 2
Training process Verification process
1 1 2–8
2 1–2 3–8
3 1–4 5–8
4 1–8 –

E¯isen (%) E¯vol (%) E¯p (%) E¯isen (%) E¯vol (%) E¯p (%) E¯isen (%) E¯vol (%) E¯p (%)
1 0.59 ± σ† 0.46 ± σ† 2.98 ± σ† 1.85 ± 1.45 3.53 ± 3.63 4.90 ± 0.97 1.69 ± 1.42 3.14 ± 3.54 4.66 ± 1.10 6.2
2 1.66 ± 1.60 0.75 ± 0.08 2.53 ± 0.84 5.78 ± 2.00 3.72 ± 2.08 4.38 ± 1.74 4.75 ± 2.61 2.98 ± 2.22 3.91 ± 1.76 14.7
3 1.54 ± 1.69 0.87 ± 0.78 3.50 ± 0.77 1.85 ± 1.28 1.54 ± 0.91 4.40 ± 0.83 1.69 ± 1.61 1.20 ± 0.97 3.95 ± 0.98 24.9

Notes: *The CPU used in these calculations is Intel E6600 at 2.4 GHz. †
For single data, the standard deviation is null. ‡
For no data, the average and the standard deviation are null.

After the training, the trained empirical constants are used in the verification process. The average relative differences between the calculated and measured isentropic efficiencies and volumetric efficiencies in the training and the verification processes are listed in Table 4. The average root mean relative difference between the calculated and measured pressure curves in the training and the verification processes are also listed in Table 4. This table shows that in the training process, the average relative differences between the calculated and measured isentropic and volumetric efficiencies are all less than 1.7 per cent. Considering the average relative differences between the calculated and measured results in the total process (the difference between the calculated and measured results in the total process is the overall average difference between the calculated and measured results in the training and verification processes), the third and fourth calculation conditions, which use more than three sets of training conditions, are more accurate than the first and second calculation conditions, which use less than three sets of training experimental conditions. The average root mean relative differences between the calculated and measured pressure curves are in the 2.53–4.9 per cent range in the training, verification, and total processes. When the adopted sets of training conditions exceed three sets, the standard deviations of the average root mean relative differences between the calculated and measured pressure curves in the total process are smaller than those that adopt less than three sets of training conditions. Hence, the stability of the numerical program is improved with more sets of training conditions. In addition to the differences between the calculated and measured results, the calculation times are also recorded in Table 4. They show that adding one set of training conditions into the training process takes an additional 6 h of calculation time. When taking accuracy and elapsed time into consideration, it is found that using four sets of training conditions provide calculated values of useful accuracy combined with acceptable computer running time.

sec.title: 3.3 The calculated pressure curves under different operating conditions
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows the pressure curves calculated by the numerical program trained under the third calculation condition, as shown in Table 4. Figure 6(a) shows the comparison between the calculated and measured PV diagrams under the eight experimental conditions listed in Table 2. Figure 6(b) shows the comparison between the calculated and measured pressures as a function of angle in the discharge process. Figure 6(a) shows that the calculated pressure curves in the compression and discharge processes are in good agreement with the experimental ones. Figure 6(b), however, indicates that there are some differences between the calculated and measured results but only in the very end of the discharge process under specific experimental conditions. The reason for these inaccuracies is that the volume of the compression chamber during the end of the discharge process is very small, causing extreme variations in pressure. To simulate the pressure curves at the end of the discharge process under all experimental conditions is difficult for the numerical program given only one set of empirical constants. Fortunately, the proportion of the area of the pressure curve in the end of the discharge process to the whole compression cycle is only 2.10 per cent. Therefore, these differences between the calculated and measured results at the very end of the discharge process do not significantly affect the overall accuracy of the calculation. Fig. 6
Comparison between the calculated and the measured pressure variations: (a) pressure as a function of volume and (b) pressure as a function of angle during the discharge process

In addition, Fig. 6(b) shows that the pressure curves in the discharge process, which are under different rotational speeds and oil-injected velocities, are only significantly different at the start (613.45–658°) and at the end (larger than 685.45°) of the discharge process. During most of the discharge process (658–685.45°) the gas is exhausted smoothly under stable pressure.

sec.title: 4 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION
sec.p:
The goal of this study is to establish a complete theoretical model and a numerical program for accurately simulating the performance and pressure–time histories of an oil-injected screw compressor under different operating conditions. In the theoretical model, seven empirical constants are used to account for the difference between the actual flow and heat-transfer rates in the screw compressor and those estimated by available correlations. The seven empirical constants are determined systematically by a training process. The main results of this study are as follows.
The comparisons of the differences between the calculated and measured results and the calculation times in the optimization show that it is efficient to train the numerical program with four sets of training conditions. In the training, verification, and total processes, the maximum disagreement for the volumetric and isentropic efficiencies is 2.0 per cent and that for the pressure curve is 5 per cent.
In the discharge process, the air pressure in the compression chamber is affected by the area of the outlet port and the pressure in the neighbouring chambers. The air pressure in the discharge process is subdivided into four sections. The first section (a) is the start of the discharge, where the outlet port is just opened and the air pressure is lower than the back pressure. The second section (b) is where the first pressure peak occurs. In the third section (c), the air is exhausted under steady pressure. In the last section (d), the second pressure peak occurs, and it has the largest amplitude.
For the pressure curve of the air, the effects of the rotational speed and the oil-injected velocity are only significant at the start and at the end of the discharge process. The influence on the pressure curve of the air is not evident in the middle of the discharge process.
This study provides a theoretical model that can fully simulate the compression processes in a screw compressor under different operating conditions and a methodology for the systematic determination of the empirical constants in the model. This methodology could be applied to different compressor designs.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This study is supported in part by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Taiwan, Republic of China under Contract 94-EC-17-A-05-I1-0006, and was technically supported by Fu Sheng Industrial Co., Limited.
